raw_text:
Deutsche Boerse set to 'woo' LSE
 
 Bosses of Deutsche Boerse and the London Stock Exchange are to meet amid talk that a takeover bid for the LSE will be raised to £1.5bn ($2.9bn).
 
 Last month, the German exchange tabled a 530 pence-per-share offer for LSE, valuing it at £1.3bn. Paris-based Euronext, owner of Liffe in London, has also said it is interested in bidding for LSE. Euronext is due to hold talks with LSE this week and it is reported to be ready to raise £1.4bn to fund a bid. Euronext chief Jean-Francois Theodore is scheduled to meet his LSE counterpart Clara Furse on Friday. Deutsche Boerse chief Werner Seifert is meeting Ms Furse on Thursday, in the third meeting between the two exchanges since the bid approach in December.
 
 The LSE rejected Deutsche Boerse's proposed £1.3bn offer in December, saying it undervalued the business.
 
 But it agreed to leave the door open for talks to find out whether a "significantly-improved proposal" would be in the interests of LSE's shareholders and customers. In the meantime, Euronext, which combines the Paris, Amsterdam and Lisbon stock exchanges, also began talks with the LSE. In a statement on Thursday, Euronext said any offer was likely to be solely in cash, but added that: "There can be no assurances at this stage that any offer will be made." A deal with either bidder would create the biggest stock market operator in Europe and the second biggest in the world after the New York Stock Exchange.
 
 According to the FT, in its latest meeting Deutsche Boerse will adopt a charm offensive to woo the London exchange. The newspaper said the German suitor will offer to manage a combined cash and equities market out of London and let Ms Furse take the helm. Other reports this week said the Deutsche Boerse might even consider selling its Luxembourg-based Clearstream unit - the clearing house that processes securities transactions. Its ownership of Clearstream was seen as the main stumbling block to a London-Frankfurt merger. LSE shareholders feared a Deutsche Boerse takeover would force them to use Clearstream, making it difficult for them to negotiate for lower transaction fees.
llama3.2:1b: Deutsche Boerse and the London Stock Exchange are discussing a potential takeover bid of £1.5bn ($2.9bn). Euronext, owner of Liffe in London, is also interested in bidding for LSE. The exchanges will have meetings on Thursday, with Deutsche Boerse chief Werner Seifert meeting LSE counterpart Clara Furse and Euronext chief Jean-Francois Theodore meeting her.
llama3.2:3b: Deutsche Boerse is set to meet with the London Stock Exchange (LSE) boss amid reports of a potential £1.5bn offer, following Euronext's similar bid of £1.4bn. LSE rejected Deutsche Boerse's initial £1.3bn offer in December but left the door open for talks. A deal would create Europe's largest stock market operator and second-largest globally after the NYSE.
gemma2:2b: Deutsche Boerse is preparing to raise its bid for the London Stock Exchange to £1.5 billion and may offer to manage a combined cash and equities market out of London while letting Ms Furse lead the LSE.  Euronext, which owns Liffe in London, may also make a bid and is willing to pay £1.4 billion. Both bidders would create the largest stock market operator in Europe.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Deutsche Boerse is set to meet with the London Stock Exchange amid talks about a potential takeover bid for LSE. The German exchange has proposed a £1.3bn offer valued at £1.5bn, which would put Euronext in a favorable position to bid. Deutsche Boerse's chief Ernst Seifert plans to meet Clara Furse on Thursday. Euronext is also preparing to discuss a cash-only deal with LSE. The LSE rejected the offer in December but acknowledged that it undervalued LSE's business. According to the FT, Deutsche Boerse will adopt a charm offensive to woo LSE and create the biggest stock market operator in Europe.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Deutsche Boerse and LSE are set to meet amid speculation of a £1.5bn takeover bid by Deutsche Boerse, which offered LSE 530 pence per share in December but was rejected by the London Stock Exchange. Euronext is interested in bidding for LSE and has indicated readiness to fund a £1.4bn offer, citing cash transactions as likely. The LSE remains open to talks, while Deutsche Boerse considers offering management or selling its Luxembourg-based Clearstream unit.
qwen2.5:3b: Deutsche Boerse and Euronext are considering bids for London Stock Exchange (LSE). Deutsche Boerse initially offered £1.3bn but LSE rejected it. A revised offer of £1.5bn ($2.9bn) is being considered, with Euronext reportedly prepared to fund this. Meetings between Deutsche Boerse and LSE have occurred, with discussions on potential integration. Euronext has also been in talks, potentially offering a cash-only bid. Deutsche Boerse may consider selling Clearstream to facilitate the deal, as its ownership of the clearing house was seen as a major obstacle to a merger with Frankfurt.
opencoder:1.5b:
The summary:
Deutsche Boerse will 'woo' the London Stock Exchange following a major merger with Euronext, including a bid of approximately £1.5bn ($2.9bn) in December.
Euronext has also said it is interested in bidding for LSE and Deutsche Boerse's proposal to negotiate a significantly-improved proposal.
The LSE has rejected the proposed cash offer during December but agreed to leave the door open for talks for further insights.
During Thursday, Euronext met with clarifications about any potential offers. The German suitor will manage a combined cash and equities market out of London.
Other reports indicated that Deutsche Boerse might consider selling its Luxembourg-based Clearstream unit for lower transaction fees. With LSE shareholders worried about the possible merger, they have also noted that Euronext may use this opportunity to create an increased stock value.

Deutsche Boerse will meet LSE, considering a £1.3bn offer but expressing interest in increasing it to £1.4bn. DB CEO meets Clara Furse on Friday for the third meeting since the initial £1.3bn bid. LSE initially rejected DB's offer but is open to alternatives. tinyllama:1.1b: The German exchange Deutsche Boerse has scheduled meetings with the London Stock Exchange and Euronext, owner of Liffe in London, to discuss a takeover bid worth £1.5bn ($2.9bn), pending the acceptance of Deutsche Boerse's latest offer, which values LSE at £1.3bn. However, Deutsche Boerse's chief Werner Seifert is meeting with Ms Furse on Thursday to discuss a "significantly improved proposal" in light of previous talks and the possibility of sell-offs for both Deutsche Boerse and Clearstream. If the merger is allowed, LSE shareholders fear that Deutsche Boerse may force them to use Clearstream for trading, making it difficult for them to negotiate lower transaction fees.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The German exchange Deutsche Boerse and the London Stock Exchange are set to engage in talks aimed at potentially raising a bid of £1.5 billion ($2.9 billion) for London Stock Exchange, according to recent reports. This would make LSE the second largest stock market operator globally after the New York Stock Exchange. The potential acquisition by Deutsche Boerse would create the biggest stock market operator in Europe and the second biggest in the world after the NYSE.

If a deal were to be reached, it would create the largest stock market operator in Europe and second-largest in the world.

In any case, a deal with either bidder would create the biggest stock market operator in Europe and the second biggest in the world after the New York Stock Exchange. According to the FT, in its latest meeting, Deutsche Boerse will adopt a charm offensive to woo the London exchange. Other reports suggest that Deutsche Boerse might even consider selling its Luxembourg-based Clearstream unit, which would make it difficult for LSE shareholders to negotiate for lower transaction fees.

Rival bidder Euronext, which owns Liffe in London, is also interested and may raise £1.4bn for a bid. Both exchanges are in talks with LSE, with Deutsche Boerse's Werner Seifert meeting LSE's Clara Furse on Thursday and Euronext's Jean-Francois Theodore meeting her on Friday. LSE rejected Deutsche Boerse’s initial bid, citing undervaluation, but remains open to a significantly improved proposal. A deal with either bidder would create Europe's largest stock market operator and the world's second-largest after the NYSE. Deutsche Boerse is reportedly adopting a charm offensive, offering to manage a combined market from London and possibly selling its Clearstream unit, which has been a key obstacle to a merger due to LSE shareholders' concerns over transaction fees.

A successful deal would create the biggest stock market operator in Europe and second largest globally after the New York Stock Exchange.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Deutsche Boerse and Euronext are set to meet with London Stock Exchange (LSE) executives amidst escalating takeover speculation. Deutsche Boerse initially proposed a £1.3bn bid in December, which LSE deemed undervalued but agreed to consider "significantly improved" offers. Euronext, owner of Liffe, has also expressed interest and is prepared to bid up to £1.4bn. Both bidders aim to create Europe's largest stock market operator and the second-largest globally, following a potential merger with the LSE. In their upcoming meetings, Deutsche Boerse will reportedly propose managing a combined cash and equities market from London and may even consider selling its Clearstream unit to address concerns about transaction fees for LSE shareholders.
